definition: A step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or accomplishing a task.
example: Finding the greatest common divisor of two numbers.

definition: A high-level description of an algorithm that is intended for human understanding rather than machine execution.
example: IF number is EVEN THEN PRINT 'Even' ELSE PRINT 'Odd'

definition: A property in algebra where an element combined with another element using one operation results in the first element.
example: For logical operations, p OR (p AND q) = p

definition: A property of some binary operations where the grouping of operands does not affect the result.
A property where the result of combining two elements from a set is also an element of the set.
example: The set of integers is closed under addition because the sum of any two integers is an integer

definition: A property of some binary operations where the order of operands does not affect the result.

Chinese: 德摩根定律 (Dé mó gēn dìnglǜ)
definition: The negation of a conjunction is the disjunction of the negations and vice versa.
example: The negation of (p AND q) is equivalent to (NOT p OR NOT q)

definition: A property where the multiplication of a number by a sum is equal to the sum of the multiplications of the number by each term in the sum.
A property where an element combined with itself results in itself.
example: For logical operations, p OR p = p

definition: An element that, when combined with another element using a binary operation, leaves the second element unchanged.
example: For addition, 5 + 0 = 5

definition: An element that does not change the value of other elements when combined with them.
example: For addition, the identity element is 0 because 5 + 0 = 5

definition: An element that, when combined with another element using a binary operation, results in the identity element.
example: The additive inverse of 5 is -5 because 5 + (-5) = 0

definition: An element that when combined with another element results in the identity element.
example: The additive inverse of 5 is -5 because 5 + (-5) = 0

definition: The first part of a conditional statement.
example: You study in the conditional statement "If you study, then you will pass the exam"

definition: A statement that two things are true at the same time, or both are false.
example: It is sunny if and only if the sky is clear

definition: A statement that if one thing is true, then another thing is also true.
example: If you study, then you will pass the exam

definition: A logical operation that results in true only if both of its operands are true.
example: It is raining and it is cold

definition: The second part of a conditional statement following the 'then'.
example: You will pass the exam in the conditional statement "If you study, then you will pass the exam"

definition: A statement that is always false.
example: It is raining and it is not raining at the same time

definition: A logical operation that results in true if at least one of its operands is true.
example: It is raining or it is sunny

definition: A statement that if one thing is true, then another thing is also true.
example: If it rains, then the ground will be wet

definition: Two statements that have the same truth value.
example: It is not raining is logically equivalent to "The sun is shining"

definition: The opposite of a statement.
example: The negation of "It is raining" is "It is not raining"

definition: A statement that contains a subject and a claim about the subject.
example: x is greater than 5

definition: A characteristic or attribute of an object or concept.
example: Being even is a property of the number 2

definition: A statement that is either true or false but not both.
example: The sky is blue

definition: A statement that is always true.
example: It will rain today or it won't rain today

definition: A table that shows the truth value of a logical expression based on the truth values of its variables.
example: A table showing all possible truth values for the statement "p AND q"

definition: The foundation value of a number system, which dictates the number of digits and their value.
example: In the decimal system, the base is 10.

definition: The numerical factor of a term in a polynomial.
example: In the term 4x, 4 is the coefficient.

definition: A number in the form \( a + bi \), where \( a \) and \( b \) are real numbers, and \( i \) is the imaginary unit.
example: \( 3 + 4i \) is a complex number.

definition: A natural number greater than 1 that is not a prime number.
example: 4 is a composite number.

definition: A number by which another number is divided.
example: 2 is a divisor of 4.

definition: An algorithm for dividing two numbers to obtain a quotient and remainder.
example: Dividing 10 by 3 gives a quotient of 3 and a remainder of 1.

Chinese: 欧几里得算法 (Ōu jǐ lǐ dé suànfǎ)
definition: An algorithm to determine the greatest common divisor of two integers.
example: The Euclidean Algorithm can find the GCD of 252 and 105.

definition: The power to which a number is raised.
example: In 2^3, 3 is the exponent / power.

definition: A number that divides another without leaving a remainder.
example: 3 is a factor of 9.

definition: The largest positive integer that divides two or more numbers without a remainder.
example: The GCD of 8 and 12 is 4.

definition: The square root of -1, denoted as \( i \).
A number that cannot be expressed as a simple fraction.
example: \( \sqrt{2} \) is an irrational number.

Chinese: k 除以 n (k chúyǐ n)
definition: The statement that a number \(k\) divides another number \(n\) without leaving a remainder.
example: 2 divides 4.

definition: The smallest positive integer that is a multiple of two or more numbers.
example: The LCM of 3 and 4 is 12.

Chinese: n 可以被 k 整除 (n kěyǐ bèi k zhěngchú)
definition: The statement that a number \(n\) can be divided by another number \(k\) without leaving a remainder.
example: 4 is divisible by 2.

definition: An expression consisting of variables and coefficients, involving terms in the form \(ax^n\).
example: \(3x^2 + 4x + 1\) is a polynomial.

definition: A natural number greater than 1 that has no positive divisors other than 1 and itself.
example: 7 is a prime number.

definition: The result of multiplying two or more numbers.
example: The product of 2 and 3 is 6.

definition: A number that can be expressed as the quotient or fraction \( \frac{a}{b} \) of two integers.
example: \( \frac{1}{2} \) is a rational number.

definition: A number that can be a rational or an irrational number.
example: \( \pi \) is a real number.

definition: An ordered list of numbers.
example: 1, 2, 3, 4, ... is an arithmetic sequence.

definition: The result of adding two or more numbers.
example: The sum of 2 and 3 is 5.

definition: A single mathematical expression or component that can be a number, a variable, or a product of numbers and variables.
example: In the expression 2x + 3, 2x and 3 are terms.

definition: The number of ways to choose k items from n items without repetition and without order.
example: Choosing 2 students out of a class of 5: 5 choose 2

definition: The product of all positive integers less than or equal to n.
An arrangement of objects in a specific order.
example: The permutations of "ABC" are ABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBA

Chinese: 包容排斥原理 (Bāoróng páichì yuánlǐ)
definition: A formula used to count the size of the union of several sets.
example: If you have two overlapping sets, the size of their union is the sum of their sizes minus the size of their intersection

definition: An equation that recursively defines a sequence or multidimensional array of values.
example: The Fibonacci sequence is defined by the recurrence relation F(n) = F(n-1) + F(n-2)

definition: A function where every element of the codomain has a pre-image in the domain.
example: f(x) = x^3 is surjective from the set of real numbers to itself

definition: A tree data structure in which each node has at most two children, referred to as the left child and the right child.
example: A structure with a root node and two subtrees.

definition: The probability of one event occurring given that another event has already occurred.
example: Given that it's raining, the probability that there's traffic

definition: A subset of possible outcomes in a probability space.
example: Drawing a heart from a deck of cards

definition: Two events that do not influence each other's occurrence.
example: Drawing two aces in a row from a deck of cards without replacement

definition: A mathematical model used to describe a random experiment.
example: Tossing a coin: {Head, Tail}

definition: A function that is both injective and surjective.
example: f(x) = x + 1 is a bijection from the set of real numbers to itself

definition: A function that is both injective and surjective.
example: f(x) = x + 1 is bijective from the set of real numbers to itself

definition: The application of one function to the results of another.
example: If f(x) = x + 2 and g(x) = 3x, then the composition g(f(x)) = 3(x + 2)

definition: A relation that maps each element of a set to exactly one element of another set.
A function where each element of the domain maps to a unique element in the codomain.
example: f(x) = x + 1 is an injection from the set of real numbers to itself

definition: A function where each element of the domain is associated with a unique element of the codomain.
example: f(x) = 2x is injective because no two different inputs have the same output

definition: A function that reverses the direction of a given function.
example: If f(x) = x + 2, its inverse is f^(-1)(x) = x- 2

definition: A function that associates each element of a set with an element of another set.
example: Mapping each student in a class to their grade in an exam

definition: A set of ordered pairs.
A function where every element of the codomain has a pre-image in the domain.
example: f(x) = x^2 is a surjection from the set of real numbers to the set of non-negative real numbers

definition: A function where every element of the codomain has a pre-image in the domain.
example: f(x) = x^3 is surjective from the set of real numbers to itself

definition: A graph that has no cycles.
example: A tree is an acyclic graph

definition: Two vertices that are connected by a single edge.
example: Vertices A and B are adjacent if there's an edge connecting them

definition: A collection of unordered lists, one for each vertex in the graph, which lists, for each vertex, its neighbors.
example: A list showing that vertex A is connected to vertices B and C

definition: A matrix used to represent a finite graph.
example: A 2x2 matrix for a graph with 2 vertices, where the entry (i, j) is 1 if there's an edge from vertex i to vertex j, and 0 otherwise

Chinese: 贝尔曼-福特算法 (Bèi'ěr màn - Fútè suànfǎ)
definition: An algorithm to find the shortest path in a weighted graph.
example: Finding the shortest path in a graph even if it has negative weight edges

definition: A graph where vertices can be divided into two disjoint sets and no two vertices within the same set are adjacent.
example: Speople= {Magda, Tyrone, Yuan} and Stask = {setTable, mowLawn, makeDinner} and edges between the tasks that people are willing to do. (There are no edges between people or between tasks, as the edges indicate a relationship between people and tasks.)

Chinese: 广度优先搜索 (Guǎngdù yōuxiān sōusuǒ)
definition: An algorithm for traversing or searching tree or graph data structures, starting at the root and exploring the neighbor nodes at the present depth prior to moving on to nodes at the next depth level.
example: Exploring a graph level by level starting from a source vertex

definition: The smallest number of colors needed to color the vertices of a graph so that no two adjacent vertices share the same color.
example: The minimum number of colors needed to color a graph with no two adjacent vertices having the same color is 2

definition: A subset of vertices of an undirected graph such that every two distinct vertices in the clique are adjacent.
example: A subset of a graph where every two vertices are connected

definition: A graph formed by switching the adjacency and non-adjacency of the original graph's vertices.
example: A graph formed by reversing the presence or absence of each edge from the original graph

definition: A graph in which there is a unique edge connecting every pair of distinct vertices.
example: A graph with 3 vertices where every vertex is connected to every other vertex

definition: A subgraph in which any two vertices are connected to each other by paths, and which is connected to no additional vertices in the supergraph.
example: All the vertices that can be reached from a given vertex

definition: A graph where there is a path between every pair of vertices.
example: A graph where there's a path between every pair of vertices

definition: A set of vertices such that each edge of the graph is incident to at least one vertex of the set.
example: A set of vertices in a graph that touches every edge

definition: A partition of the vertices of a graph into two disjoint subsets.
example: Dividing a graph into two disjoint subgraphs

definition: A path in a graph that starts and ends at the same vertex.
example: A path in a graph that starts and ends at the same vertex without revisiting any vertex

definition: The number of edges incident to a vertex.
example: In a graph, the vertex with 3 edges connected to it has a degree of 3

definition: A list of the degrees of the vertices in a graph.
example: For a graph with vertices of degrees 2, 2, and 1, the degree sequence is (2, 2, 1)

Chinese: 深度优先搜索 (Shēndù yōuxiān sōusuǒ)
definition: An algorithm for traversing or searching tree or graph data structures by exploring as far as possible along each branch before backtracking.
example: Exploring a graph by going as deep as possible before backtracking

Chinese: 迪杰斯特拉算法 (Dí jié sī tè lā suànfǎ)
definition: An algorithm to find the shortest path between nodes in a graph.
example: Finding the shortest path from a source vertex to all other vertices in a weighted graph

Chinese: 有向无环图 (Yǒuxiàng wú huán tú)
definition: A directed graph with no cycles.
example: A directed graph with no cycles, like a tree

definition: A graph where each edge has a direction.
example: A graph where each edge has a starting and ending vertex

definition: A line connecting two vertices in a graph.
example: A line connecting two vertices in a graph

definition: A cycle in a graph that visits every edge exactly once.
example: A circuit that visits every edge of a graph exactly once

definition: A path in a graph that visits every edge exactly once.
example: A path in a graph that visits every edge exactly once

Chinese: 有限数量的边 (Yǒuxiàn shùliàng de biān)
definition: A graph that has a countable number of edges.
example: A graph with exactly 5 edges

definition: A directed graph where each edge has a capacity and each edge receives a flow.
example: A directed graph representing the flow of goods from source to sink

definition: A disjoint set of trees.
example: A collection of disjoint trees

definition: A collection of vertices and edges.
example: A collection of points (vertices) and lines (edges) connecting some of the points

definition: An assignment of colors to the vertices of a graph such that no two adjacent vertices have the same color.
example: Assigning colors to a graph such that no two adjacent vertices have the same color

definition: A bijective correspondence between the vertex sets of two graphs that preserves adjacency.
example: Two graphs that have the same structure but may have different vertex or edge labels

Chinese: 哈密尔顿回路 (Hā mǐ'ěr dùn huílù)
definition: A cycle that visits every vertex of a graph exactly once.
example: A cycle in a graph that visits every vertex exactly once and returns to the starting vertex

Chinese: 哈密尔顿路径 (Hā mǐ'ěr dùn lùjìng)
definition: A path in a graph that visits each vertex exactly once.
example: A path that visits every vertex of a graph exactly once

definition: A matrix that shows the relationship between vertices and edges in a graph.
example: A matrix showing the relationship between vertices and edges in a graph

definition: Two graphs that have a one-to-one correspondence between their vertices and edges.
example: Two graphs that look different but have the same structure

Chinese: 克鲁斯卡尔算法 (Kè lǔ sī kǎ'ěr suànfǎ)
definition: An algorithm to find the minimum spanning tree of a graph.
example: An algorithm to find the minimum spanning tree of a graph

definition: A set of edges without common vertices.
example: A set of edges in a graph where no vertex is repeated

definition: A spanning tree with weight less than or equal to the weight of every other spanning tree.
example: A spanning tree with the least total edge weight

definition: A graph which is permitted to have multiple edges, also called parallel edges, between any two vertices.
example: A graph that can have multiple edges between the same vertices

definition: Multiple edges that connect the same two vertices.
example: Two edges in a graph that connect the same two vertices

definition: A sequence of vertices where each adjacent pair is connected by an edge.
example: A path from A to C through B in a graph

definition: A graph that can be embedded in the plane such that no edges intersect.
example: A graph that can be drawn on a plane without any edges crossing

Chinese: 普里姆算法 (Pǔ lǐ mǔ suànfǎ)
definition: An algorithm to find the minimum spanning tree of a connected graph.
example: Another algorithm to find the minimum spanning tree of a graph

definition: A graph where each vertex has the same degree.
example: A graph where every vertex has a degree of 2

definition: An edge that connects a vertex to itself.
example: An edge in a graph that connects a vertex to itself

definition: A path with no repeated vertices.
example: A path from A to C without revisiting any vertex

definition: A tree that connects all the vertices of a graph.
example: A tree that connects all vertices of a graph

definition: A set of vertices in a graph, no two of which are adjacent.
example: A subset of a graph where no two vertices are connected

definition: A graph formed from a subset of the vertices and edges of another graph.
example: Taking vertices {A, B} and the edge connecting them from a larger graph

definition: A linear ordering of the vertices of a graph such that for every directed edge (u, v), vertex u comes before vertex v in the ordering.
example: Ordering the vertices of a graph such that for every directed edge (u, v), u comes before v

definition: A connected graph with no cycles.
example: A graph with no cycles and only one path between any two vertices

definition: A graph where edges have no direction.
example: A graph where each edge simply connects two vertices

definition: A point in a graph.
example: A point in a graph

English: Vertex Degree (In-degree and Out-degree for directed graphs)
French: Degré de sommet (Degré entrant et sortant pour les graphes dirigés)
Spanish: Grado de vértice (Grado de entrada y salida para grafos dirigidos)
Chinese: 顶点度 (有向图的入度和出度) (Dǐngdiǎn dù (yǒuxiàng tú de rù dù hé chū dù))
definition: The number of edges incident to a vertex. In directed graphs, in-degree is the number of incoming edges and out-degree is the number of outgoing edges.
example: For a directed graph, the in-degree of a vertex is the number of edges coming into it, and the out-degree is the number of edges going out of it

definition: A sequence of vertices and edges in a graph where each edge's end vertex is the next edge's start vertex.
example: Moving from vertex A to B to C in a graph

definition: A graph where each edge has a weight or cost associated with it.
example: A graph where each edge has a value (e.g., distance between two cities)

Chinese: 基础情况 (对于归纳法) (Jīchǔ qíngkuàng (duìyú guīnà fǎ))
definition: The starting point of a mathematical induction, proving the statement for the first value.
example: For the statement P(n) = "1 + 2 + ... + n = n(n+1)/2", the base case is P(1), which is 1 = 1(1+1)/2

definition: The statement derived from negating both the hypothesis and conclusion of a conditional statement and swapping them.
example: If a number is not odd, then it's even.

definition: A proof that demonstrates the truth of a statement by a straight chain of logical deductions.
example: To prove that the sum of two even numbers is even.

definition: The claim that there exists at least one element in a domain for which a predicate is true.
example: There exists an x in the set of integers such that x^2 = 4 (x can be 2 or -2)

Chinese: 归纳步骤 (对于归纳法) (Guīnà bùzhòu (duìyú guīnà fǎ))
definition: The step in mathematical induction where the statement is proven for the general case.
example: For the statement P(n) = "1 + 2 + ... + n = n(n+1)/2", the inductive step is proving that if P(k) is true, then P(k+1) is also true

definition: A proof that divides the problem into several cases and proves each one individually.
example: Proving that for any integer n, n^3-n is divisible by 3.

definition: A proof that establishes the truth of a statement by assuming its negation is true and then showing that this leads to a contradiction.
example: Proving that the square root of 2 is irrational by assuming it's rational.

definition: A proof technique that assumes the statement holds for all previous cases to prove it for the next case.
example: Proving that every amount of postage of 12 cents or more can be made using just 4-cent and 5-cent stamps

definition: The claim that a predicate is true for all elements in a domain.
example: For all x in the set of real numbers, x + 0 = x

definition: A proof technique that assumes the statement holds for some arbitrary case and proves it for the next case.
example: Proving that for all natural numbers n, 1 + 2 + ... + n = n(n+1)/2

definition: The number of elements in a set.
example: The set {apple, banana, cherry} has a cardinality of 3.

definition: The set of all ordered pairs of elements from two sets.
example: The Cartesian product of {1, 2} and {A, B} is {(1, A), (1, B), (2, A), (2, B)}

definition: The set containing elements that are not in a given set.
example: The complement of {apple, banana} in {apple, banana, cherry, date} is {cherry, date}

definition: An infinite set that can be put into one-to-one correspondence with the set of natural numbers.
example: The set of all integers

definition: The set containing elements that are in one set but not in another.
example: The difference of {apple, banana, cherry} and {banana, cherry} is {apple}

definition: An individual object in a set.
example: apple is an element of the set {apple, banana, cherry}

definition: A set with no elements.
A relation that is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.
example: The relation "is the same age as" on a set of people

definition: A set with a limited number of elements.
A set with an unlimited number of elements.
example: The set of all natural numbers

definition: The set containing all elements that are in both of two sets.
example: The intersection of {apple, banana} and {banana, cherry} is {banana}

definition: The set of all subsets of a set.
example: The power set of {apple, banana} is {{}, {apple}, {banana}, {apple, banana}}

definition: A subset that is not equal to the original set.
example: {apple, banana} is a proper subset of {apple, banana, cherry}

definition: A relation where every element is related to itself.
example: {(1, 1), (2, 2)} is reflexive on the set {1, 2}

definition: A collection of distinct objects.
example: {apple, banana, cherry}

definition: A set that contains only elements that are also in another set.
example: {apple, banana} is a subset of {apple, banana, cherry}

definition: A relation where if an element a is related to an element b, then b is related to a.
example: {(1, 2), (2, 1)} is symmetric

definition: A relation where if an element a is related to an element b, and b is related to an element c, then a is related to c.

Chinese: 不可数无限 (Bù kě shǔ wúxiàn)
definition: An infinite set that cannot be put into one-to-one correspondence with the set of natural numbers.
example: The set of all real numbers between 0 and 1

definition: The set containing all elements that are in either of two sets.
example: The union of {apple, banana} and {banana, cherry} is {apple, banana, cherry}
